marc:datafield.marc:subfield: William Few was a statesman, Revolutionary soldier, and banker, of Georgia and New York.

Collection includes letters concerning the Creek Indians in Georgia, the location of the national capital, and routine business letters; letter from Benjamin Few concerning militia activities during the Revolutionary War and the Creek Indians; and miscellaneous papers, including a summons, an indenture, and a bill of sale for seventy slaves belonging to Ignatius Few.
Obadiah Fields was a slave trader from Rockingham County, N.C.
Letters and papers of a slave trader with data on slave prices and the territory of Obadiah Field's trade.

Letter from Thomas Fitzsimons (1741-1811), merchant and statesman, in his capacity as chairman of the board of trustees of the University of Pennsylvania to Benjamin Williams, president of the trustees of the University of North Carolina, concerning admissions policies.
John Fitzgerald was a plantation owner, merchant, and apparently a school official, of Nottoway County, Va.

Collection includes business and personal correspondence. Included are references to tobacco sold, insurance, and a trip in 1870 by rail and steam from Virginia to Moscow, Ky., by way of Cincinnati. There are also a number of applications for teaching positions at Oak Grove Academy, Nottoway County.
Amory Fisher was a businessman and resident of Tuscaloosa (Ala.).

Amory Fisher made cotton gins and spinning machines in Tuscaloosa, Al. The collection includes correspondence to his brother, Leonard Fisher, in Bangor, Me. The letters describe living conditions in Alabama, and also a family trip to Tennessee by wagon.
Elizabeth D. Fitzhugh was a resident of Fredericksburg, Va.
Personal letters containing some genealogical information particularly relating to the Catlett and Taliaferro families.
John Ficklen was a resident of Fredericksburg, Va.
Personal letters of John Ficklen to his future wife, Sally A. Slaughter, including a description of a journey from Fredericksburg, Virginia, to Halifax.
Millard Filmore (1800-1874) was the thirteenth president of the United States.

Papers of Millard Fillmore (1800-1874), including a land grant, a pardon, a letter from Horace Webster (1794-1871) concerning the financial affairs of Geneva College, Geneva, New York, and a letter to the Rev. Dr. John Chase Lord (1805-1877) pertaining to Lord's sermon, Higher Law and the Fugitive Slave Bill (1851).
Lindley Fisher was a resident of Philadelphia, Pa.
Business papers, one concerning Francis Bach and Co.
William A. J. Finney was a member of a firm of slave traders, of Museville (Pittsylvania Co.), Va.

This collection contains business, Civil War, and political correspondence, giving a detailed picture of methods of conducting and financing the slave trade, with accounts of purchases in Virginia, Louisiana, and Mobile and Montgomery, Alabama. Included are notices regarding the slave market in Richmond. Civil War letters show that many members of the Finney family were in the Confederate Army. There are references to Finney's attempts to raise a company, his hiring of a substitute, the battle of Big Bethel, the maintenance of the Danville Railroad, and appeals for food. Letters of the 1870s pertain to Finney's political activities in Virginia.
Hamilton Fish was a statesman who resided in Washington D.C., and New York City.
Social correspondence between Hamilton Fish, and L.P. de Cernola; Henry Whitney Bellows; John B. Floyd; and, Samuel Jackson Randall.
William H. Fielding was a farmer and Confederate soldier, from South Carolina.

Papers include letters referring to the war in South Carolina and Virginia, the testing of an African American's loyalty to the South, a measles epidemic, and conditions at Summerville and Sullivan's Island, S.C.; and a list of men serving in "Beat Company, No. 2, 42nd Regiment, First Battalion."
John Fifer was a Union soldier, member of the 84th Indiana Infantry Regiment, from Muncie (Delaware Co.), Ind.
Personal letters from Fifer to his wife, containing references to troop movements principally in Tennessee.
R.S. Fitch was a resident of Fleming County (Ky.), and a soldier.
Letters from R. S. Fitch, a private in the Federal Army, chiefly to Margaret Shanklin, describing his army experiences and commenting on camp life.
Clinton Bowen Fisk was a U.S. Army officer and official in the Freedmen's Bureau, and a resident of New York, NY.
Letter from Clinton Bowen Fisk (1828-1890) to General Leonard Fulton Ross concerning the position of his brigade; and a personal letter to Irene E. Gilbert, a former associate at Fisk University.
Danial J. Flanders was a commanding officer of the 6th New Hampshire Heavy Artillery; later resident of Buxton (York County), Maine.

Personal letters discussing camp life, U.S. Sanitary Commission field hospitals and physicians, food and clothing, pillaging by Federal troops, the siege of Petersburg, Lee's surrender, and Confederate prisons.
James J. Findley was a Confederate Cavalry officer, from Milledgeville (Baldwin Co.), Ga.
Principally orders and sub-vouchers of Colonel James J. Findley, in command of the 1st Regiment, Georgia State Cavalry, C.S.A.
Greenville First Baptist Church was located in Greenville, S.C.
The collection includes the church's Sixth Annual Report (Jan. 9, 1910, for 1909), Seventh Annual Report (Jan. 8, 1911), and an undated chart of financial statistics.
